children.subject: Thank you for the transparency!

when I work with students on research, it's really a 1:1 flavor education and about seeing if there is a great path that student can be on for the next years (less so than about exactly where they are at today)

when teaching, it's about making sure students are ready now, and otherwise they can always take the course next year;  the above metrics ensure students will be ready + favor the students who are maximally ready;  there are always exceptions b/c no metric is ever perfect, that's why there is also (iii) above in case there is some particular other ways students demonstrate readiness for a true grad level course ;  key thing I have in mind here is that the course needs to be maximally catered to the grad students (b/c that's the purpose of the course), and that means (since it's unavoidable to teach to the middle) ensuring all students are at comparable level to the grad students, hence some metrics to help ensure;  also by doing it this way, students can make their schedules now, rather than having lots of uncertainty about when the course finally starts how many people will drop because the homework was too hard and open up a spot for them etc...

I think that the simple reality of class size constraints imposes hard decisions on instructors and students alike. This semester, admission into CS294-158 (also taught by Professor Abbeel) was based on similarly high requirements at first. I think the mindset is that lack of sufficient background will leave students struggling to catch up to the grad students, who are ofc the primary audience of the course.

Hey Professor Abbeel - 

I’m a bit conflicted why there are such high requirements for this class while you also say you support alleviating barriers to activities like research in a program like DARE (https://dare.berkeley.edu/). How did you come up with these academic guidelines (particularly interested in “9 A+s” as a metric)?
yes, the current plan is to webcast
What would I miss out on if I solely watched the webcasts and self learned the material through the online slides and assignments?
It's like any other course, really. You miss out on a lot of engagement by not being present.
This might be a long shot, but do you plan on webcasting the course? There is another class also offered at this time and I'd ideally like to take both
any Berkeley courses
Time for me to take some PE courses...
lmao
lol, this was exactly my thought when I saw Prof Abbeel's reply
What type of courses (department, units, etc.) count towards the overall 9 A+ grades?
Yes, I believe so..
yes, for these categories of students, it'll be handled similar to undergrads -- i.e. with permission of instructor, following philosophy listed above

5th year MS students don't actually unlock phase 1 until July, so we would actually then be better off if we were able to apply as undergrads. Is there any way we can be admitted now/June and have an enrollment code reserved for us that we wouldn't be able to use until July/August?
that's fine

Just to clarify, if we are part of the 5th year MS program, can we email to get a permission code for the class in fall now, and then enroll once we unlock our phase I? Or should I wait until June to apply for a permission code (I currently have between 7-8 A+ overall depending on final grades this semester, so as an undergrad I would have to wait until June).
yes, you can email now

I see that the seats reserved for "Students not in the Master of Engineering and not in the 5th Year MS in Engineering Programs." Is the 5th Year MS EECS program a "5th Year MS in Engineering Program"?
they'll still be covered

Is the current plan for the course to get rid of the reinforcement learning components (like policy gradients, Continuous MDP's, Policy Search stc) because of overlap with CS 285, or will some of these topics still be covered? Or is this all still mostly up in the air? Thanks!
Would taking 287 be possible/useful even without taking 189? i.e. are there any prerequisites for the class beyond having the grade requirements? Thank you.
Hey! did you get any updates? I also emailed him for this class.
Hi, just wondering if you received a reply at some point?
Have all the spots for undergrads been taken already? If we didn't receive a reply to the email does that mean we didn't get in?
I am in EECS 5th Yr Master. I got an enrollment code from the professor, but I am still placed onto the wait list.

I reached out to Prof. Abbeel, we're currently figuring out what happened. I'll post an update when it's resolved.


Status: reached out to CS enrollments, waiting for response

Update: I believe this is resolved, you should be enrolled in the class now
Did anyone who received a code in May/June and/or are 5th year masters students manage to get enrolled or were you placed on the wl?

Hi, 

I emailed Professor a couple weeks back but haven't heard back. Should I follow-up? Just wanted to double check as I was super interested in this class. Thanks!

history.content:
Hi!

CS287 has recently been expanded (from 50 to 150) to allow more students to enroll.  

Enrollment policy for CS287 is first-come-first-served, and by default only grad students can register.  

Undergraduate students will also be admitted into the class through instructor permission on a case-by-case basis.  Here is how this will work:

May: on first-come-first served basis undergrads will be admitted if:

(i) they attained 3A+ grades in any subset of the following courses: CS188, CS189, CS182, EE126, EE127 

OR (ii)  they attained 9A+ grades (or more) in their course work overall

OR (iii) I (=Abbeel) give them special individual permission (e.g. per particularly relevant research + strong coursework that almost reaches above criteria)

June: same, but under (I) 2A+ suffices; under (ii) 6A+ suffices

July, August: same but under (i) 1A+, 1A suffices; under (ii) 3A+, 3A suffices

The way to go through this process is to email me at pabbeel@cs.berkeley.edu with subject line: *CS287 undergrad enrollment*, and make sure to include your latest transcript and resume + 1 paragraph on why you want to take CS287. 

If you didn’t make it in during May, don’t count on me reading your original email again in June, instead make sure to email me again at that time (and same in July, August).

On the course content itself: Syllabus will probably very similar to the most recent offering, https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~pabbeel/cs287-fa15/, with maybe 30% updates, mostly to be determined as the semester progresses; and with the Matlab-based homework exercises converted in python.

— Pieter
history.subject: F19: CS287 Advanced Robotics -- enrollment
